intro: Psyllocarpus itakangapyra, commonly known as the black mangrove, is a species of flowering plant in the family Malvaceae. It is native to the coastal regions of Southeast Asia, including parts of Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines. The plant is characterized by its dark, almost black bark and its ability to thrive in saline and waterlogged soils. It has small, elliptical leaves and produces yellowish flowers that are clustered in terminal panicles. The fruit is a capsule that splits open to release tiny, wind-dispersed seeds.
